CatDescriptText: Obie Griffin, policeman, 7334 Hermitage Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 15, 1959, pg. B1 with question: "Do you believe judges give society proper protection by refusing to send confessed murderers, guilty of murder in the first degree, to the electric chair?" answer reads: "If the crime warrants this man to be sent to the electric chair, I think that he should get the supreme penalty. Nobody wants to die, therefore, for any person to deliberately take a life, he should be made to pay the supreme penalty.  For instance, the other day, in 'Battle of Chicken Hill,' the battle was with a thug called Galto who had shot at a policeman on a previous occasion."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Obie Griffin wearing dark hat with plaid band, light colored t-shirt, and light colored short sleeved shirt with flower in top button hole, standing on sidewalk in front of Jenkins Arcade and Bud Saunders Flowers, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
